stem: Complete the assessment findings for a client with a chest tube to water seal.
template: Continuous bubbling in the water seal chamber suggests {{failure}}. The nurse expects to see {{normal}} in the water seal chamber when the client breathes.

options: an air leak in the system
blanks.correctOption: an air leak in the system

rationale.correct: Water seal chamber logic: (1) Tidaling is normal (reflects pleural pressure changes). (2) Constant bubbling indicates a break in the closed system (Air Leak). Intermittent bubbling is normal for a pneumothorax until the air is removed.
rationale.incorrect: Suction bubbling occurs in the *suction control chamber*, not the water seal.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "an air leak in the system" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "tidaling (fluctuation with breath)" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

clinicalPearls: If tidaling stops, it either means the lung has fully re-expanded (Good) or the tube is kinked/blocked (Bad).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Identify *which* chamber the question refers to. Suction chamber (Constant bubbling OK). Water seal (Constant bubbling BAD).

reviewUnits.heading: Chest Tube Drainage Systems
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor drainage volume (Call MD if >100mL/hr), maintain the system below the chest level, and keep sterile gauze/petroleum at the bedside for emergencies.
